thread.title: Driver killed after police pursuit 'didn't deserve to die for traffic offences'
thread.title_full: Driver killed after police pursuit 'didn't deserve to die for traffic offences'

author: Elizabeth Byrne
title: Driver killed after police pursuit 'didn't deserve to die for traffic offences'
text:
Map: Canberra 2600 
The mother of a man who died after being pursued by police in Canberra's south has told a coronial inquest her son "was no innocent but did not deserve to die for traffic offences". 
Timothy Smith-Brown, 24, died in a three-car crash in September 2015 , seriously injuring his heavily-pregnant girlfriend and three other people. 
Police had chased Mr Smith-Brown on suspicion of traffic violations, at speeds of more than 180 kilometres per hour. 
Seconds before Mr Smith-Brown's car crossed a red light and hit another car, the controller ordered officers to terminate the pursuit. 
Police witnesses have differed in their opinions over when the chase should have been abandoned. 
Today his mother, Joanne Smith, made an impassioned statement to the inquest into her son's death. 
She said police should have given thought to who may have been in the car, adding that she needed the officer driving to understand the devastating ramifications his decisions had for her family. 
"I know he did wrong, I know he had a terrible driving record," she said. 
"I am not trying to say he was an innocent, but my son did not deserve to die for traffic offences." Couple injured in crash were friends of family 
Ms Smith also revealed today that a couple badly hurt in one of the other cars were long-time friends of her family. 
"Tim would have been shattered by the suffering they endured," she said. 
"I am so sorry for what happened to them." 
Ms Smith said her other son, who was largely housebound and depended on his brother, had suffered overwhelming loss and devastation. 
She said part of her died when she heard the news. 
"I knew I would never feel joy again," she said. 
"You never get over the death of a child. I will never heal." 
Ms Smith said the saddest part was that her grandson Tim, born one day after the accident , would grow up without his father and with a mother who was too injured to care for him. 
No date has been set for a final ruling in the inquest.
